sections.header: Detox Your Ex: Stop Craving Their Texts

lessons.title: Your Brain On Breakup: Why It Feels Like Withdrawal
lessons.subtitle: This is not you being dramatic, this is your nervous system freaking out.
lessons.tldr: Breakup cravings are a dopamine crash, not proof you should go back.
lessons.action: When the urge hits, drink cold water, take 6 slow exhales, and name the feeling.

quote.text: I thought missing them meant we were meant to be. Turns out my brain just wanted the hit.

quiz.question: You wake up craving their text. What‚Äôs the first move?

options.text: Scroll their socials to see if they posted
Label the craving and take slow breaths
Send a long paragraph to get closure

quiz.explanation: Naming the craving and regulating your breath lowers the urge without relapsing.

quiz.question: Why does heartbreak feel like withdrawal?

options.text: Your reward circuits are crashing after losing consistent dopamine
You are weak at handling emotions
Because they were your soulmate

quiz.explanation: Dopamine pathways are adjusting to no longer receiving the old hits of attention.

content: Romantic love lights up the same reward circuits in your brain as addictive apps, sugar, and substances, so when the relationship ends it literally feels like losing your favorite drug.
Your body starts searching for the old hits of validation and attention, which is why you catch yourself stalking, rereading chats, or waiting for their name to pop up on your screen.
Once you understand this is a brain chemistry crash, not proof that they were your soulmate, you can stop romanticizing the pain and start treating it like a detox phase you will move through.

lessons.title: No-Contact, But Make It Powerful (Not Petty)
lessons.subtitle: No contact is not a mind game, it is a self-respect move.
lessons.tldr: No-contact is a quiet room for your brain to heal, not a revenge play.
lessons.action: Write your no-contact contract: duration, rules, and who you text instead when urges hit.

quote.text: The minute I muted them, my head stopped spinning long enough to actually feel calm.

quiz.question: You get a dry ‚Äúhey‚Äù from them during no-contact. Best response?

options.text: Reply to stay polite
Screenshot to friends, then keep no-contact
Write a long message explaining boundaries

quiz.explanation: Keep the boundary. Share with trusted friends if you need support, but don‚Äôt re-open the loop.

quiz.question: What is the point of no-contact?

options.text: To make them chase you
To get quiet so your mind stops negotiating your worth
To punish them

quiz.explanation: It is a healing buffer that protects your nervous system from constant re-triggering.

content: Going no-contact is less about punishing them and more about finally giving your mind the quiet it needs to heal, think clearly, and stop negotiating your own worth.
Every time you reply to a dry text, check if they watched your story, or keep the streak alive, you are feeding the same loop that broke you in the first place.
Decide your no-contact rules in advance, write them down, and treat them like a contract with your future self, so when the urge hits you follow the plan instead of the impulse.

lessons.title: Block, Mute, Archive: Digital Rules For A Real Reset
lessons.subtitle: If your phone is a trigger, you need boundaries, not more willpower.
lessons.tldr: Your feed trains your brain; clean it so you are not fighting triggers every scroll.
lessons.action: Block or mute their accounts for 30 days and follow 5 calming, growthy creators instead.

quote.text: Once I muted them, my screen stopped dragging me back into the past every two minutes.

quiz.question: Why block or mute during healing?

options.text: To be dramatic
To reduce constant triggers and cravings
To make them jealous

quiz.explanation: Removing triggers lowers the intensity of cravings so you can heal faster.

quiz.question: Best digital reset move tonight?

options.text: Re-read old chats to remember the good parts
Archive the chat and follow accounts that make you feel grounded
Leave notifications on just in case

quiz.explanation: Curating your feed toward calm and growth keeps your brain from looping.

content: Your brain cannot heal if every scroll shows their face, their new posts, or old memories sitting in your chat list waiting to be reopened at 1 a.m.
Blocking, muting, or archiving is not overreacting, it is clearing the mental clutter so you are not fighting a boss-level temptation every time you unlock your phone.
Curate your feed with accounts that make you feel grounded, inspired, and seen, so your screen starts reinforcing your healing instead of dragging you back into the past.

lessons.title: Catching Yourself Before The "Just One Text" Relapse
lessons.subtitle: The urge to send a long paragraph is usually a sign you need closure from you, not from them.
lessons.tldr: The fantasy text keeps you hooked; a pause and a body reset break the loop.
lessons.action: Write the message in Notes, set a 5-minute timer, then do a 60-second body reset.

quote.text: I typed the whole paragraph, left it in Notes, and avoided a three-day spiral.

quiz.question: You want to send a long text at 1 a.m. What‚Äôs step one?

options.text: Send it so you can sleep
Type it in Notes and pause
Ask friends to text them for you

quiz.explanation: Getting it out without sending defuses the craving and protects your progress.

quiz.question: After writing it down, what helps the urge pass?

options.text: Scroll their profile to feel something
Do a 60-second body reset (shake, breathe, step outside)
Re-read the chat history

quiz.explanation: Regulating your body lowers the emotional spike so you can choose, not react.

content: The 'just one text' fantasy usually sounds like you explaining everything perfectly and them finally getting it, apologizing, and fixing the past.
In reality, that text often leads to another confusing reply, another fight, or another wave of disappointment that sets your healing back days or weeks.
When the urge hits, pause for five minutes, write the message in your notes instead, and then do one small regulating action for your body so the craving passes without you reopening the door.

lessons.title: Turning Heartbreak Into Main-Character Plot Fuel
lessons.subtitle: If this is your villain origin story, you also get to write the comeback arc.
lessons.tldr: Heartbreak is data: use it to raise standards and build your next season.
lessons.action: List 3 non-negotiables you ignored and 3 micro-moves you‚Äôll start this week.

quote.text: Plot twist: the breakup became the season where I built a life I actually like.

quiz.question: What‚Äôs the goal after heartbreak?

options.text: Prove to them you‚Äôre fine
Use the energy to upgrade your standards and routines
Wait until they come back

quiz.explanation: Directing the energy toward your standards and habits builds your next chapter.

quiz.question: Best first step tonight?

options.text: Write a list of what you refuse to tolerate again
Scroll old photos to feel motivated
Text them you‚Äôre working on yourself

quiz.explanation: Clarifying non-negotiables teaches your brain what safe love should look like.

content: Every breakup exposes where you abandoned yourself, ignored your needs, or accepted crumbs, which makes this the perfect moment to upgrade your standards.
Instead of only asking why they did what they did, start asking what this version of you refuses to tolerate ever again and what future you actually deserves.
Use the energy from the heartbreak to fuel a season of building: better habits, better boundaries, better environments, and a life so full that getting them back stops being the main goal.

sections.header: Main Character Energy: Rebuild Your Identity

lessons.title: You Are Not Their Opinion: Reclaiming Your Self-Image
lessons.subtitle: The breakup did not downgrade your value, it just removed the wrong mirror.
lessons.tldr: Their projection is not your identity; collect proof of who you are now.
lessons.action: Write three receipts of your strengths today and screenshot them for later dips.

quote.text: Their version of me was tiny. My friends‚Äô version reminded me I wasn‚Äôt.

quiz.question: Why isn‚Äôt their opinion the truth about you?

options.text: Because they saw you on your worst day
Because their view was filtered through their own wounds
Because opinions never matter

quiz.explanation: People project their fears and immaturity; it is not an accurate mirror.

quiz.question: Quick way to rebuild self-image tonight?

options.text: List three strengths and when you used them recently
Stalk their new relationship
Ask them to rate you again

quiz.explanation: Collecting receipts of your strengths trains your brain toward self-trust.

content: When someone pulls away, cheats, or treats you like an option, your brain quickly starts building a story that you were not enough, even if their behavior had nothing to do with your worth.
Their version of you was filtered through their own wounds, immaturity, and fears, which means it was never an accurate reflection, just a projection they put on you.
Your job now is to unfollow that story and consciously collect proof of who you actually are: your strengths, your growth, your values, and the way people who truly care show up for you.

lessons.title: From "We" To "Me": Rewriting Your Daily Routine
lessons.subtitle: If your whole day was built around them, it is time to redesign the schedule around you.
lessons.tldr: Empty time slots are space to build your own rituals, not to panic-fill with them.
lessons.action: Swap one ex-related time slot with a 15-minute micro-win (walk, learn, stretch).

quote.text: My evenings were ghost-town quiet until I made them my workout-and-music hour.

quiz.question: Why redesign your routine after a breakup?

options.text: To stay busy so you never think
To plug in habits that recharge you instead of orbiting them
To make them jealous

quiz.explanation: Intentional routines make your energy less dependent on their presence.

quiz.question: Good first swap?

options.text: Replace nightly texting with a 15-minute walk + music
Keep the old calls but shorter
Scroll late to feel sleepy

quiz.explanation: A small, repeatable habit gives your brain a new anchor at that time.

content: Breakups feel extra empty when your habits, calls, and check-ins used to orbit around another person and suddenly there is just silence in those time slots.

Instead of trying to fill that silence with random distractions or rebound conversations, intentionally plug in routines that recharge you: movement, learning, journaling, or small wins for your goals.
Treat your day like a personal playlist you curate on purpose so your energy is no longer dependent on whether they text or not.

lessons.title: Hobbies, Side Quests, And Finding Your Thing Again
lessons.subtitle: Main characters have side quests, not just side characters.
lessons.tldr: Side quests make your story bigger than dating; pick ones that feel like play.
lessons.action: Try one 30-minute throwback hobby this week and note how it felt before/after.

quote.text: Painting for 20 minutes beat doomscrolling every time once I actually started.

quiz.question: Why add side quests?

options.text: To look busy online
To expand your identity beyond dating
To brag to your ex

quiz.explanation: Hobbies remind you who you are when no one else is defining you.

quiz.question: Best way to pick a hobby?

options.text: Return to something you loved as a kid and try it for 30 minutes
Wait for motivation to appear
Choose whatever your ex liked

quiz.explanation: Revisiting low-pressure interests makes it easier to start and enjoy.

content: Relationships can make you slowly drop the hobbies, interests, and weird little passions that used to make you feel alive before you met them.
Start by revisiting things you liked as a kid or teen before you cared what anyone thought‚Äîart, games, music, sports, writing, building something, anything that makes you lose track of time.
Your goal is not to become hyper-productive, it is to remember what lights you up when no one is watching so your life feels bigger than just dating.

lessons.title: Social Glow-Up: Curating A Circle That Actually Sees You
lessons.subtitle: You don‚Äôt just need people around you, you need people who are for you.
lessons.tldr: Notice who steps up and who drains you; invest where you feel safe to be real.
lessons.action: Text one friend who made you feel seen this week and plan a low-key hang.

quote.text: I realized the friends who checked on me without drama were the ones I wanted to grow with.

quiz.question: What‚Äôs a green flag in your circle?

options.text: They hype you when you set boundaries
They only call when they need a favor
They joke about your feelings

quiz.explanation: Friends who celebrate your boundaries keep you aligned with your growth.

quiz.question: Quick social reset move?

options.text: Plan a small hang with a friend who made you feel seen
DM your ex‚Äôs circle to stay in the loop
Isolate until you feel better

quiz.explanation: Quality connection boosts regulation and reminds you who you are.

content: After a breakup, some people disappear, some stay neutral, and a few quietly step up for you‚Äîpay attention to who lands in which category.
Start giving more time and emotional access to the friends who hype your growth, hold you accountable, and make you feel safe to be honest instead of judged.
Healing becomes way easier when your environment is full of people who remind you who you are, not just who you were with your ex.

lessons.title: Future You Would Be Proud: Designing Your Next Chapter
lessons.subtitle: If your life is a series, this breakup is just the end of one season, not the show.
lessons.tldr: Script future you in 6‚Äì12 months and back it up with tiny weekly moves.
lessons.action: Write a 6-month mini-vision and pick two tiny steps you can do this week.

quote.text: Once I wrote what future-me was doing, texting my ex felt off-script.

quiz.question: Why script future you?

options.text: To control every detail
To aim your energy at what you want instead of the past
To make your ex jealous

quiz.explanation: A clear direction reduces the pull to revisit old storylines.

quiz.question: Solid first step?

options.text: Write a 6-month vision and two tiny steps for this week
Wait for motivation to appear
Ask your ex what you should work on

quiz.explanation: Small, immediate steps make the vision feel real and build momentum.

content: Instead of obsessing over what you lost, start scripting what future you wants to be feeling, doing, and surrounded by six to twelve months from now.
Break that vision down into tiny, realistic moves you can start this week: a new skill, a healthier habit, a money goal, a boundary you finally enforce.
The more you invest in that next chapter, the less appealing it becomes to go back to a storyline where you kept shrinking yourself to keep the peace.

sections.header: Red Flag Radar: Never Miss The Signs Again

lessons.title: Love Bombing vs. Real Effort: Spotting The Difference
lessons.subtitle: Not every intense connection is healthy‚Äîsome are just fast-tracked chaos.
lessons.tldr: Love bombing is fast and flashy; real effort is steady and paced.
lessons.action: Pause fast escalations for 72 hours before agreeing to big plans or labels.

quote.text: He planned a future in week one. The ones who took it slow felt safer.

quiz.question: Which is love bombing?

options.text: Week-one future plans and constant intense messages
Consistent check-ins over weeks at your pace
Respecting your boundaries when you say no

quiz.explanation: Fast intensity without history can be manufactured chemistry.

quiz.question: How to respond to fast escalation?

options.text: Match their speed to keep them interested
Pause for 72 hours and see if actions stay consistent
Ghost them immediately

quiz.explanation: Time reveals if the intensity is backed by steady respect.

content: Love bombing feels like a movie montage at the start: constant compliments, long calls, big promises, and a rush that makes you ignore how little time you actually know this person.
Real effort builds slowly and consistently over time, with actions that match words and a pace that respects your comfort instead of pushing you to commit before you even feel grounded.
If the connection feels like a high you are scared to lose rather than a calm you can relax into, that intensity might be a red flag, not proof that they are "the one."

lessons.title: Mixed Signals Are Still A Signal (And It‚Äôs Not Green)
lessons.subtitle: If you have to decode their behavior like it is a puzzle, the answer is already no.
lessons.tldr: Mixed signals equal unclear interest; clarity feels obvious and steady.
lessons.action: Ask one direct question about intention; if the answer is foggy, step back.

quote.text: I stopped being their translator. If it was unclear twice, I exited.

quiz.question: Mixed signals usually mean?

options.text: They are shy but obsessed
They enjoy your energy but avoid commitment
They test your patience so you‚Äôll prove love

quiz.explanation: Inconsistency often signals low readiness, not hidden devotion.

quiz.question: Best move when you feel confused twice?

options.text: Decode harder with friends
Ask directly, then step back if it stays vague
Accept crumbs to keep them around

quiz.explanation: Directness plus distance protects your peace when clarity is missing.

content: Mixed signals look like heavy flirting one day and cold distance the next, sweet words with zero follow-through, or someone who wants your energy but avoids real commitment.
When you care, it is tempting to become their personal therapist, excuse-maker, and translator, constantly telling yourself they are just "busy," "confused," or "not ready."

Clear interest feels obvious, steady, and safe, so if you are anxious-refreshing chats and asking all your friends what that last text meant, your body is picking up a red flag your mind is trying to ignore.

lessons.title: When Chemistry Made You Ignore Compatibility
lessons.subtitle: The spark was real, but so were the reasons it couldn‚Äôt work.
lessons.tldr: Chemistry is a vibe; compatibility is the foundation. You need both.
lessons.action: List three non-negotiable values and check them before date three.

quote.text: The spark was üî• but he didn‚Äôt want the same future. That was the whole answer.

quiz.question: Why isn‚Äôt chemistry enough?

options.text: It guarantees loyalty
It can hide value clashes that matter long term
It means the relationship will be boring

quiz.explanation: Shared values and maturity sustain a relationship after the spark settles.

quiz.question: Smart move after a high-spark first date?

options.text: Check your values list before date three
Ignore differences if the chemistry is insane
Assume it will work out because it feels special

quiz.explanation: Using your values as a filter keeps you from excusing red flags.

content: Chemistry can make you feel like you have found your person on the first date, but long-term relationships are built on boring-sounding things like values, goals, communication, and emotional maturity.
You can be insanely attracted to someone who is not ready for commitment, doesn‚Äôt want the same future, or cannot show up consistently, and that is not something you can fix with more love.
Looking back at when you overrode your intuition, your standards, or your non-negotiables "because the connection was different" helps you train yourself to choose compatibility over chaos next time.

lessons.title: Bare Minimum Energy: Why You Kept Accepting Less
lessons.subtitle: Answering your texts is not a personality trait or a grand gesture.
lessons.tldr: Bare minimum is the floor, not the prize; raise the bar to normal.
lessons.action: Write four basics you expect (honesty, consistency, respect, time) and treat them as default.

quote.text: I was calling basic decency a ‚Äògreen flag.‚Äô Never again.

quiz.question: What counts as bare minimum?

options.text: Honesty, consistency, respect, time
Buying gifts monthly
Reading your mind

quiz.explanation: These are baseline requirements, not bonuses.

quiz.question: Why do people accept less?

options.text: Fear of being alone or thinking they won‚Äôt find better
Because they have too many options
Because high standards are rude

quiz.explanation: Low self-worth and scarcity mindset keep you tolerating crumbs.

content: When your self-worth quietly slips, you start treating basic decency‚Äîlike replying, not lying, or spending time with you‚Äîas if it is elite behavior you should be grateful for.
You might have stayed because you were scared of being alone, thought you would never find better, or believed that if you just loved them right, they would finally step up.
Recognizing where you lowered the bar helps you raise it back to normal: consistency, honesty, respect, and effort are the starting point, not the prize.

lessons.title: Building Non-Negotiables So You Don‚Äôt Repeat The Past
lessons.subtitle: Standards are not you being picky; they are you protecting your peace.
lessons.tldr: Non-negotiables are your safety rails; use them as a filter, not a wishlist.
lessons.action: Pick 3 non-negotiables and one dealbreaker; exit early when they are crossed.

quote.text: Writing my non-negotiables made it way easier to leave when they failed basics.

quiz.question: How should you use non-negotiables?

options.text: As a cute list you ignore when chemistry hits
As a filter you act on early
As a way to test people secretly

quiz.explanation: They are meant to guide decisions, not decorate notes.

quiz.question: Good first move when a non-negotiable is broken?

options.text: Hope it changes with time
Address it once, then exit if it repeats
Lower the standard

quiz.explanation: Protecting your peace means leaving when core needs are dismissed.

content: Non-negotiables are the few core things you refuse to compromise on again, like emotional availability, communication style, or how conflict is handled.
Instead of making the list aesthetic and then ignoring it when someone attractive shows up, use it as an actual filter: if they fail the basics early, you exit early.
Every time you walk away from someone who cannot meet your standards, you teach your brain that you are safe with yourself‚Äîand that is the real upgrade.

sections.header: Soft Life Reset: Calm Your Nervous System

lessons.title: Overthinking At 2AM: Getting Out Of The Thought Spiral
lessons.subtitle: Your brain loves drama at night; you don‚Äôt have to attend every mental argument.
lessons.tldr: Night brain is dramatic; park thoughts for daylight and calm your body.
lessons.action: Write worries in Notes labeled ‚Äútomorrow,‚Äù then do 10 slow breaths before sleep.

quote.text: Parking the thoughts till morning stopped the 2 a.m. courtroom in my head.

quiz.question: Why do problems feel bigger at night?

options.text: Your brain has fewer distractions so worries get louder
You are secretly dramatic
The problems grow at night

quiz.explanation: Quiet hours give rumination more space; daylight brings perspective.

quiz.question: Best 2 a.m. move?

options.text: Decide your life plan immediately
Dump worries into Notes and breathe slowly
Text your ex for answers

quiz.explanation: Externalizing the thoughts and calming your body reduces the spiral.

content: Nighttime makes small problems feel massive because your brain has fewer distractions and more space to replay every conversation, text, and red flag on loop.

Instead of trying to "think your way" out of the spiral, give your mind a different job: write down the worries in a note, label them as "tomorrow problems," and gently bring your focus back to your body or your breath.
You are allowed to decide that 2AM is not the time for life decisions and train yourself to revisit those thoughts in the daylight when your nervous system is calmer.

lessons.title: Body First, Feelings Second: Simple Nervous System Hacks
lessons.subtitle: You can‚Äôt mindset your way out of a dysregulated body.
lessons.tldr: Regulate your body before you debate your feelings; calm first, analyze second.
lessons.action: Pick one reset: cold splash, slow exhale breathing, or 5-4-3-2-1 grounding.

quote.text: My thoughts went from ‚Äòpanic‚Äô to ‚Äòokay‚Äô after I just did the cold water trick.

quiz.question: Why start with the body?

options.text: Feelings aren‚Äôt real
A regulated body makes thoughts less extreme
Breathing is trendy

quiz.explanation: Calming the nervous system lowers the fight-or-flight response.

quiz.question: Which is a fast reset?

options.text: Cold water on face + long exhales
Argue in your head for an hour
Post a rant story

quiz.explanation: Physical grounding interrupts the panic loop quickly.

content: When your heart is racing, your chest is tight, or your stomach drops after a trigger, your nervous system is in survival mode, and no amount of "just don‚Äôt care" talk will fix it.
Start with simple grounding moves: cold water on your face, slow exhale-focused breathing, pressing your feet into the floor, or naming five things you can see in the room.
Once your body feels even a little safer, your thoughts instantly become less extreme, and you can respond instead of react.

lessons.title: Trading Drama For Peace (Without Feeling Boring)
lessons.subtitle: Peace is not boring; you‚Äôre just detoxing from emotional rollercoasters.
lessons.tldr: Calm can feel weird at first; give your body time to adjust from chaos.
lessons.action: Schedule one ‚Äòquiet block‚Äô daily where you do something low-drama and notice the calm.

quote.text: Silence felt empty until week two‚Äîthen it felt like actual peace.

quiz.question: Why can peace feel boring?

options.text: You are meant for chaos
Your body is detoxing from adrenaline highs
Peace means you lost your spark

quiz.explanation: Your system is used to spikes; stability takes adjustment.

quiz.question: How to get used to calm?

options.text: Add a daily quiet block with a low-drama activity
Pick a fight to feel alive
Scroll arguments online

quiz.explanation: Practicing calm teaches your body that peace is safe, not dull.

content: If you grew used to chaotic relationships, stable connections and quiet days can feel uncomfortable, empty, or even wrong at first.
Your brain might miss the highs and lows because they created adrenaline and intensity, but that doesn‚Äôt mean those dynamics were good for you.
The more you choose calm over chaos‚Äîblocking arguments, not engaging with bait, leaving when energy feels off‚Äîthe more your system learns that peace is actually the flex.

lessons.title: Micro-Habits That Quiet Anxiety After A Text Or Trigger
lessons.subtitle: You don‚Äôt need a full routine; sometimes you just need a 30-second reset.
lessons.tldr: Build tiny automatic resets so triggers don‚Äôt hijack your whole day.
lessons.action: Pick one go-to move when triggered: stand, shake, sip water, and 10-count breathe.

quote.text: A 30-second shake + water stopped me from doom-texting more than once.

quiz.question: What‚Äôs a micro-reset?

options.text: A 30‚Äì60s action that calms your body
A three-hour spa day
Posting about your ex

quiz.explanation: Short, repeatable moves keep triggers from spiraling.

quiz.question: You see their name pop up. Best first move?

options.text: Stand up, shake out, sip water, slow breathe
Reply fast to stop anxiety
Scroll their profile

quiz.explanation: Resetting your body first keeps you in control of the next choice.

content: Anxiety spikes fast when you see their name pop up, spot a reminder, or hear a song that takes you straight back to them.
Instead of spiraling, build tiny go-to habits: stand up and shake out your body, step outside for fresh air, drink some water, or put your phone face down and breathe slowly for ten counts.
These micro-resets teach your brain that you can feel a wave of emotion and still stay in control, without replying, stalking, or self-sabotaging.

lessons.title: Soft Life Standards: What You Will And Won‚Äôt Tolerate Now
lessons.subtitle: Soft life is not laziness; it‚Äôs intentional protection of your energy.
lessons.tldr: Soft life means guarding your peace with clear yes/no lists.
lessons.action: Write 3 things you refuse now (arguing in DMs, unclear situationships, repeats of broken trust) and 3 things you welcome.

quote.text: Once I priced my peace higher, messy people disqualified themselves fast.

quiz.question: What is soft life here?

options.text: Avoiding all effort
Choosing environments and relationships that feel safe and supportive
Never leaving bed

quiz.explanation: It is intentional protection of your energy, not laziness.

quiz.question: First step to set soft-life standards?

options.text: List 3 nos and 3 yeses for your energy
Let others decide for you
Say yes to every invite

quiz.explanation: Clarity on your yes/no list guides quick, peaceful decisions.

content: Soft life after heartbreak means choosing environments, conversations, and relationships that feel safe and supportive instead of loud and draining.
Make a short list of what you refuse to entertain now‚Äîarguing in DMs, second chances for the same behavior, situationships with no clarity‚Äîand what you welcome instead.
The more you act like your peace is expensive, the more your future connections will have to rise to that level or lose access to you.
